description: From Middle English pacquet; either from Middle French pacquet, or formed independently from pak and -et.

entries.meaning: A small pack or package; a little bundle or parcel
examples: Don't throw the crisp packet on the floor!
(archaic) a travel bag containing clothing, nightwear and other accessories.

entries.meaning: (nautical) Originally, a vessel employed by government to convey dispatches or mails; hence, a vessel employed in conveying dispatches, mails, passengers, and goods, and having fixed days of sailing; a mail boat. Packet boat, ship, vessel (Wikipedia).
(botany) A specimen envelope containing small, dried plants or containing parts of plants when attached to a larger sheet.
(networking) A small fragment of data as transmitted on some types of network, notably Ethernet networks (Wikipedia).

examples: It'll cost a packet to fix this.

verbs.description: packet (third-person singular simple present packets, present participle packeting, simple past and past participle packeted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make up into a packet or bundle.
(transitive) To send in a packet or dispatch vessel.
(intransitive) To ply with a packet or dispatch boat.
(transitive, Internet) To subject to a denial-of-service attack in which a large number of data packets are sent.
examples: Typically, one hacker will annoy another; the offended party replies by launching a denial-of-service attack against the offender. These attacks—known as packeting—tend to be of limited duration  […]
